newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy upbeat on EU GDP/deficit forecast.
newsitem.headline: Italy upbeat on EU GDP/deficit forecast.

text.p: Italy said on Tuesday that it would be extremely satisfied if European Commission figures due out on Wednesday show the country coming close, though not quite meeting, the 1997 budget deficit target for the single currency.

A Treasury Ministry spokesman made the remark in response to an unconfirmed report by an Italian news agency that the forecast would show Italy with a deficit to Gross Domestic Product (GDP) ratio of 3.3 percent.
The target for membership of European economic and monetary union is 3.0 percent.
"Our judgment would be extremely positive in so far as that would seem to confirm that Italy's deficit/GDP ratio is only a few decimal points above three percent," the spokesman said.
The European Commission is due to publish its findings for all EU states at 1100 GMT on Wednesday.
Italy has drawn up a 62.5 trillion lire budget for 1997, now going through parliament, to try to make the grade for EMU membership from its planned start in January 1999.
The spokesman said the Commission would not have been able to take account of all financial measures being drawn up by Italy's centre-left government, including a planned one-off "Euro tax."

He said the Commission forecast of the servicing costs of Italian public debt would also necessarily be based on interest rates which were now out of date following the Bank of Italy's move on October 23 to cut its key discount rate to 7.50 percent from 8.25 percent.
